frameDefinitions: A Convoy consists of several Vehicles which move together to transport Cargo from a Source to a Goal.
An Agent causes a Theme to move from a Source, along a Path, to a Goal.
The words in this frame describe motion involving a Vehicle and someone who controls it, the Driver.
This frame has to do with nouns denoting types of entities.

This frame is concerned with the idea that people (Participant_1, Participant_2, or Participants) participate in an organized, rule-governed activity (the Competition) in order to achieve some advantageous outcome (often the Prize).
This frame concerns the movement of a Theme and an Agent and/or Carrier.
frameExamples: A <t><fex name='con'>convoy</fex></t> of several dozen vehicles was stopped at the border for several hours while border guards inspected their cargo.
She <t>threw</t> her shoes into the dryer .
Tim <t>drove</t> his car all the way across North America.
I don't like this newfangled <t><fex name='Subtype'>kind</fex></t> of  fish.
Karl <t>carried</t> the books across campus to the library on his head.
listRoleDefinitions: The constituent vehicles that make up the <fen>Convoy</fen>.
The group of vehicles transporting the <fen>Cargo</fen>.
The <fen>Cargo</fen> are the goods and/or individuals transported by the <fen>Convoy</fen>. This role also covers the intended use of the transported goods.

People and possibly other elements of the convoy who support and defend the transport of the <fen>Cargo</fen> are the <fen>Support</fen>. In military contexts, this typically consists of soldiers and military vehicles who provide defense for the conveying <fen>Vehicles</fen> and <fen>Cargo</fen>.
The general Place where the <fen>Convoy</fen> is operating.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one whose action causes the motion of a <fen>Theme</fen>.  The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally realized as the External Argument.
The role <fen>Theme</fen> is generally an NP Object.
The role <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of motion.
The role <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor <fen>Goal</fen>.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the point at which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

The role <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element.
<fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to be set in motion.
A resultant state that the <fen>Theme</fen> is in at the end of its motion.
A previous state that the <fen>Theme</fen> was in before the beginning of its motion.
The time at which the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that provides a setting for a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
This is the being, typically human, that controls the <fen>Vehicle</fen> as it moves.
This is the means of conveyance controlled by the <fen>Driver</fen>.  It may move in any way or medium.  With verbs, <fen>Vehicle</fen> is usually expressed as Object:

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>. This includes directional expressions and 'middle of path'' expressions, e.g.:

Any expression which tells where the moving object(s) ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
The  <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Driver</fen> operates the <fen>Vehicle</fen>
The <fen>Place</fen> describes the location of a more specific motion (which has <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The entity which denotes a subtype of the more general <fen>Category</fen>.
The more general type that the target denotes a subtype of. This role is obligatory and should be labeled DNI when not present.
This role identifies the first (or only) participant in a competition.
This role identifies the second participant in a competition.
This role is used for plural NP participants in a competition.
This role is used for the name of the competition.
The period of time when the <fen>Competition</fen> occurs.

Where the event takes place. 
A constituent tagged as <fen>Place</fen> may require annotation on a secondary FE-layer.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is a sentient being who physically controls the movement of the <fen>Theme</fen> via the carrier, accompanying the <fen>Theme</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the endpoint of the path.
<fen>Source</fen> indicates the beginning of the path along which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
Path along which carrying occurs.
The objects being carried.
<fen>Area</fen> is used for descriprion of a general area in which the carrying action takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path.
The <fen>Carrier</fen> provides support for the <fen>Theme</fen>.  Movement of the <fen>Carrier</fen> results in movement of the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The time in which the carrying event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that serves as a setting for the specific motion of the <fen>Agent</fen> and <fen>Theme</fen> (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
listRoleExamples: Trained gunmen hijacked a <fex>20-car</fex> convoy headed for the city.
The southbound <fex>convoy</fex> of two vans and several armored vehicles arrived safely 10 hours after it had departed.
Trained gunmen hijacked a <fex>medical supply</fex> convoy headed for the city.
A military convoy <fex>of rebel gunmen</fex> stood between us and a large cache of weapons.
Convoys <fex>in Afghanistan</fex> have been hardest hit.
<fex>Pat</fex> threw the china at the wall.
Pat threw <fex>the china</fex> at the wall.
Pat dragged the box <fex>out of the cupboard</fex>.
I pushed the trolley <fex>along the street</fex>.
Kim threw the cat <fex>into the garden</fex>.
Kim pushed the lawnmower <fex>around the garden</fex>.
<fex>The storm</fex> tossed the sailor from the boat
The fireman dragged the injured driver <fex>clear</fex>
Paul pulled Fran upright <fex>from her sitting position</fex>.
We shoved half of the cargo overboard <fex>on the 29th</fex>.
<fex>Kim</fex> drove my old car cross-country.
I drove <fex>my car</fex> to Canada.
Kim drove <fex>out of town</fex>.
The bikers rode <fex>through the desert</fex>.
Kim drove <fex>into the parking lot</fex>.
The bikers rode <fex>all over the place</fex>.
<fex>Yesterday</fex>, Smithers paddled his boat across the lake and back
I don't like this <fex>kind</fex> of fish.
They created a new breed <fex>of dog</fex>.
<fex>Jo</fex> played the lottery every day.
Jo played <fex>Leslie</fex> at tennis.
<fex>Jo and Leslie</fex> played tennis.
Jo played <fex>in the foosball tournament</fex>
First layer: John's first competition <fex>at Wimbledon</fex> astonished the crowd.
<fex>Karl</fex> carried the books across the campus to the library.
Karl carried the books <fex>to the library</fex>.
Karl hauled the books <fex>from the library</fex>  to the office.
Karl carried the books <fex>across the campus</fex>.
Karl toted <fex>the books</fex> to the car.
<fex>The boat</fex> ferried the troops across the river.
<fex>Even in such a small port</fex>, these boats would transport many tons of trade-goods in to shore annually.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Royal Societyfor the Protection of Birds
